ResourceHeader.ResourceName: Gold Level L2 ratio of the column abundance of thermospheric O relative to N2
ResourceHeader.Description:
GOLD daytime disk scan (DAY) measurements are used to derive the ratio of the column abundance of 
	  thermospheric O relative to N2, conventionally referred to as O/N2 or ΣO/N2, but abbreviated to ON2 for the GOLD 
	  data product. ON2 is derived for each valid dayside Level 1C pixel for approximately 68 disk scan measurements 
	  performed per day by GOLD in nominal operation.
	  
	  Algorithm heritage
      The disk ON2 retrieval algorithm was originally developed by Computational Physics, Inc. (CPI) for use with 
	  GUVI and SSUSI radiance images (Strickland et al., 1995). The GOLD implementation of this algorithm takes 
	  advantage of GOLD’s ability to transmit the full spectrum to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio and eliminate 
	  atomic emission lines that contaminate the N2 LBH bands (e.g., N I 149.3 nm). This algorithm has been 
	  extensively documented and applied over the past several decades (e.g., Evans et al. [1995]; 
	  Christensen et al. [2003]; Strickland et al. [2004]).

	  Algorithm theoretical basis
      The geophysical parameter retrieved, O/N2, is the ratio of the vertical column density of O relative to N2, 
	  defined at a standard reference N2 depth of 1017 cm-2, which is chosen to minimize uncertainty in the derived 
	  O/N2. It is retrieved directly from the ratio of the O I 135.6 nm and N2 LBH band intensities measured by GOLD 
	  on the dayside disk (DAY measurement mode). The AURIC atmospheric radiance model (Strickland et al. [1999]) is 
	  used to derive this relationship as a function of solar zenith angle and to create the look-up table (LUT) used 
	  by the algorithm.

      References
      Christensen, A. B., et al. (2003), Initial observations with the Global Ultraviolet Imager (GUVI) in the NASA 
	  TIMED satellite mission, J. Geophys. Res., vol. 108, NO. A12, 1451, doi:10.1029/2003JA009918.
	  
      Evans, J. S., D. J. Strickland and R. E. Huffman (1995), Satellite remote sensing of thermospheric O/N2 and 
	  solar EUV: 2. Data analysis, J. Geophys. Res., vol. 100, NO. A7, pages 12,227-12,233.
	  
      Strickland, D. J., R. R. Meier, R. L. Walterscheid, J. D. Craven, A. B. Christensen, L. J. Paxton, D. Morrison, 
	  and G. Crowley (2004), Quiet-time seasonal behavior of the thermosphere seen in the far ultraviolet dayglow, 
	  J. Geophys. Res., vol. 109, A01302, doi:10.1029/2003JA010220.
	  
      Strickland, D.J., J. Bishop, J.S. Evans, T. Majeed, P.M. Shen, R.J. Cox, R. Link, and R.E. Huffman (1999), 
	  Atmospheric Ultraviolet Radiance Integrated Code (AURIC): theory, software architecture, inputs and selected 
	  results, JQSRT, 62, 689-742.
	  
      Strickland, D. J., J. S. Evans, and L. J. Paxton (1995), Satellite remote sensing of thermospheric O/N2 and 
	  solar EUV: 1. Theory, J. Geophys. Res., 110, A7, pages 12,217-12,226.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: National Aeronautics and Space Administration; Dr. Richard Eastes

NumericalData.ProviderResourceName: Gold Level L2 Molecular Oxygen Density Profile

Parameter.Name: Mask Defining OI 1356 Bandpass
Parameter.Description: Wavelength mask defining OI 1356 bandpass used in retrieval.

Parameter.Name: Random Uncertainty in N2 LBH
Parameter.Description: Random uncertainty in N2 LBH brightness.

Parameter.Name: Lookup Table
Parameter.Description: Lookup table filename.

Parameter.Name: Mask Wavelength
Parameter.Description: Wavelength grid for MASK_N2_LBH and MASK_OI_1356.

Parameter.Name: OI 1356 brightness
Parameter.Description: OI 1356 brightness used in retrieval.

Parameter.Name: GOLD channel
Parameter.Description: GOLD channel (‘A’ or ‘B’).

Parameter.Name: Latitude
Parameter.Description: Pixel latitude.

Parameter.Name: Retrieved O/N2 column density ratio
Parameter.Description: Retrieved O/N2 column density ratio used in QEUV retrieval.

Parameter.Name: Random Uncertainty in Oxygen 135.6 nm Brightness
Parameter.Description: Random uncertainty in oxygen 135.6 nm brightness.

Parameter.Name: Random Uncertainty in O/N2 Ratio
Parameter.Description: Random uncertainty in retrieved O/N2 column density ratio.

Parameter.Name: Overall Quality Flag
Parameter.Description: NMAX data quality index (see table below).

Parameter.Name: Scan Start Time
Parameter.Description: UTC start time of scan, e.g., "2017-06-21T23:46:38.015Z".

Parameter.Name: Solar Zenith Angle at 225 km
Parameter.Description: Solar zenith angle at 225 km tangent point.

Parameter.Name: Longitude
Parameter.Description: Pixel longitude.

Parameter.Name: O/N2 Ratio Quality Flag
Parameter.Description: ON2 data quality index per pixel (see table below).

Parameter.Name: Systematic Uncertainty in O/N2 Ratio
Parameter.Description: Systematic uncertainty in retrieved O/N2 column density ratio.

Parameter.Name: Model Uncertainty in O/N2 Ratio
Parameter.Description: Model uncertainty in retrieved O/N2 column density ratio.

Parameter.Name: Systematic Uncertainty in N2 LBH brightness
Parameter.Description: Systematic uncertainty in N2 LBH brightness.

Parameter.Name: UTC time
Parameter.Description: UTC date/time string: "2017-06-21T23:46:38.015Z".

Parameter.Name: Mask Defining LBH Bandpass
Parameter.Description: Wavelength mask defining LBH bandpass used in retrieval.

Parameter.Name: L1C File Name
Parameter.Description: L1C file name for each occultation.

Parameter.Name: N2 LBH brightness
Parameter.Description: N2 LBH brightness used in retrieval.

Parameter.Name: Pixel Emission Angle
Parameter.Description: Pixel emission angle (relative to zenith).

Parameter.Name: Scan Stop Time
Parameter.Description: UTC stop time of scan, e.g., "2017-06-21T23:46:38.015Z".

Parameter.Name: Systematic Uncertainty in Oxygen 135.6 nm Brightness
Parameter.Description: Systematic uncertainty in oxygen 135.6 nm brightness.

Parameter.Name: Hemisphere Scanned
Parameter.Description: Hemisphere scanned (‘N’ or ‘S’).
